profileText: a Representative from Alabama; born on a plantation near Columbus, Muscogee County, Ga., April 1, 1846; born enslaved; self-educated; moved to Alabama and engaged in agricultural pursuits; member of the Alabama state house of representatives, 1870-1872; member of the Alabama state senate, 1872-1875; elected as a Republican to the Forty-fourth Congress (March 4, 1875-March 3, 1877); unsuccessful candidate for election to the Forty-fifth Congress in 1876; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Forty-sixth Congress in 1878; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Forty-ninth Congress in 1884; appointed to a Federal position in the United States customhouse in Baltimore, Md.; later employed as a clerk in the Interior Department; appointed August 12, 1882, to the Pension Bureau in Washington, D.C., and resigned August 21, 1884; pension agent, Pine Bluff, Ark., 1891-1894; convicted on December 8, 1894, of forgery; sentenced to prison and fined; circumstances and date of death unknown.

researchRecord.description: A letter from Jere Haralson to the United States Centennial Commission in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania written on April 27, 1876. In the letter, Haralson requests an additional invitation for his wife to attend the opening of the Centennial International Exhibition of Industry.
